III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility is a two-story older home located in a residential neighborhood on the
northside of the city of Kalamazoo. Staff and youth will enter the facility through the
backdoor off the driveway. Upon entering the facility, is a landing with stairs leading
to the basement straight ahead and stairs leading up into the facility on the right.
There is a door at the bottom of the basement stairs and youth will have no access
to the basement. The basement is locked and is used for extra storage, along with
utility appliances. Going up the stairs to the right you enter a hallway leading left at
the top of the stairs. This hallway has a full bathroom on the left and a laundry room
on the right. The hallway leads to the kitchen which has the staff office off to the
right. Moving straight through the kitchen you enter the living room. This is a large
room and moving straight through this room you can enter a sunroom with a bank of
windows on three sides. Off the right of the living room is a second entrance room
with stairs leading up the upper level where the bedrooms are located. To the left of
this entrance room is a doorway leading to a porch and the front door of the facility.
The upper stairs has a landing and change direction to the right. Once at the top of
the stairs, there is a bedroom to the right. This is a large room with three windows
with two large closets. Currently there is one bed in this room and the facility has
another bed but is going to start with only one youth in the room before bringing the
second bed. Coming out of this room and moving down the hallway, there is a
second bedroom to the right which is also large, has two windows and has one large
closet. As with the other bedroom, there is a bed and a second bed will be brought in
as the number of youth grows. Across the hall is another full bathroom. Going to the
end of the hall is a third large bedroom with three windows with a built in cabinet and
large closet. There are two beds in this room and the means of egress is the same
as the other two bedrooms. Each bedroom meets the requirements for dual
occupancy and each bedroom has the required window for emergency rescue. All

the plumbing fixtures are in working order with both cold and hot running water and
flushing toilets. There are appropriate working fire extinguishers that are up to date
throughout the facility. Overall, this facility is decent shape and maintained
appropriately. The fire inspection was completed on 4/28/22 with an “A” rating. The
environmental inspection was completed on 4/27/22 with an “A” rating.
B. Program Description
LTAI IV DD/CI is a residential facility located in Kalamazoo, MI with a mission
statement of “Empowering and equipping youth for success beyond foster care”.
This is a six bed non-secure treatment program with a design to help higher
functioning youth with developmental disability and/or cognitive impairment develop
the skills necessary for future placements. This program will serve adolescent boys
between the ages of 10 - 17 who have a history of abuse/neglect, struggles with
mental stability, has developmental disabilities and/or cognitive impairments. Youth
eligible for this program, must be ambulatory, must be able to perform activities of
daily living, and must not be medically fragile.
Services provided are tailored to meet each individual resident’s identified treatment
needs and permanency goals. A licensed Masters Level Social Worker (LMSW)
provides counseling (individual and/or family). This program provides an intensive,
broadly structured setting that will provide for the needs of each youth on an
individual basis. Each youth will be evaluated in a team setting involving the referring
worker, other service providers and family members to develop a comprehensive
individualized treatment plan. The treatment goals will consider the level of
functioning of each youth. Family members will be asked to invest themselves in the
program with a focus on helping them understand the strengths and limitations of the
youth and to learn about the effects of trauma on the youth.
Services provided in this program are described as follows: Daily program will help
build the youth’s ability for independent living skills along with evaluating their needs
for aftercare services. Both psychiatric and psychological assessments will help
develop the treatment goals and as well as trauma assessments, ACE assessments,
biopsychosocial assessments, medical and dental assessments, and any other
assessments that are determined to be necessary. Trauma focused therapy will be
provided, both individually and in a group setting. Several adjunctive therapies will
be provided, ranging from recreational therapy to music therapy. Educational and
employment services will be provided and based on the needs and goals of the
youth and their educational involvement will be monitored. Beginning at intake,
aftercare planning will be developed, and this will be an ongoing process during their
stay in the program. Other services such as substance abuse education, family
activity programs, and education about healthy sexual choices will be added as
determined by the ongoing assessment of the youth. Transportation for any
appointments (court, medical, visits, schooling, etc.) will be provided by the program.
The program will collaborate with several community agencies to provide as many
experiences as necessary to help in the healing process of the youth.
3

Youth in the program will be supervised 24/7 by trained staff. Staff providing different
services such as therapy, assessments and passing medication will all be licensed
according to their requirements and trained in the service they will be providing. Any
medical services such as nursing will also be licensed appropriately and be trained
in the processes for this program. All treatment planning will involve all individuals
invested in the youth’s life such as referral source, parents, therapy providers,
assessment specialists, staff of the program and the youth. The program will work
closely with the youth’s school and provide additional services if needed or required
by the schooling assessment. Upon discharge the youth will be followed by the
aftercare specialist who will provide the appropriate aftercare services based on
Service Level 1 or Service Level 2. Development of the aftercare (transition) plan will
begin at entrance to the program with input from several sources involved in the
youth’s life. A Family Team Meeting will be facilitated to ensure input from all
individuals and to ensure they have knowledge of the aftercare plan.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are no Rule/Statutory violations.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that a 6-month original license be provided to this facility.
